instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3208: What is 820-3208? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.5V_S3: What is 5V_S3? 5V_S3 is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S3” which is a 5 volt power rail present in an S3 state. S3 (Suspend to RAM) is a state where the system saves its context to RAM, a faster but more power-consuming method than S4. The system shuts down most components except for RAM, which remains powered to retain the system state. PM_SLP_S4_L is required for this rail to be present. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.5V_S0: What is 5V_S0? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S0”.
definitions.P5VS0_EN: What is P5VS0_EN? This signal enables the PP5V_S0 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A always orange no fan spin
threads.message:
this board came to me when turning on and immediately when reaching login window it shuts down.
I took the MLB for inspection under the mic and found corrosion on <RESISTOR>R1300</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R1310</RESISTOR> which i replaced and bridge properly and thought that about it but no no, the machine now won't 
start orange light on and no fan spin.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> on <RESISTOR>R5301</RESISTOR> - stable 8.38
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_SW_TBTBST</SIGNAL> on <CAPACITOR>C3890</CAPACITOR> - 2.58
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> on <CAPACITOR>C7621</CAPACITOR> 8.38
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL> for some reason can't be found on the .brd
<SIGNAL>DCIN_S5_VSENSE</SIGNAL> - 16.48
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> on <RESISTOR>R6995</RESISTOR> - 3.40

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A always orange no fan spin
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A always orange no fan spin
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A always orange no fan spin
threads.message: Check all other S3 and S0 voltages. <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> is present so the power sequence is starting but one of the rails is missing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A always orange no fan spin
threads.message: Do you mean those?[ATTACH alt="Screen Shot 2016-11-04 at 19.09.48.png" type="full" width="1440px"]9189._xfImport[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A always orange no fan spin
threads.message: Any bus with S3 and S0, 1v8 1v05 etc. All <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> are tied together so only need to check 1 for every rail same for all others.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A always orange no fan spin
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A always orange no fan spin
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A always orange no fan spin
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 9252"]Voltage on <RESISTOR>R7913</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7978</RESISTOR>[/QUOTE]

I wanted to test <RESISTOR>R7978</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7913</RESISTOR> when i attached the probe which is standard size i touched <RESISTOR>R1814</RESISTOR> and got fan spin, I bridged the to and connected to the system, now it runs high but no screen and no post.
Update: I removed the bridges i done and now back to point 1 no fan and orange light.
<RESISTOR>R7978</RESISTOR> - 3.32
<RESISTOR>R7913</RESISTOR> / 3.40 pin 1 (<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> ) pin 2 (<SIGNAL>P5VS3_EN</SIGNAL>) 3.37

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A always orange no fan spin
threads.message: <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> enable comes straight from <RESISTOR>R7978</RESISTOR> so youngest have <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL>!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A always orange no fan spin
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 9303"]<SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> enable comes straight from <RESISTOR>R7978</RESISTOR> so youngest have <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL>![/QUOTE]

ok so what could cause it to show 3.32?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A always orange no fan spin
threads.message: If you have <SIGNAL>P5VS0_EN</SIGNAL>, go check voltages on the <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> FET, engage some brains.
